name: Nagas
shortDescription: Serpent beings with human and snake features, guardians of treasures and waters, rulers of the underworld
fullDescription: Nagas (Sanskrit: ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó, NƒÅga; feminine: NƒÅgƒ´ or NƒÅginƒ´) are a race of serpent beings in Hindu, Buddhist, and Jain mythology, capable of assuming human or serpentine form. They are typically depicted as human from the waist up with a cobra hood or multiple serpent heads, and serpentine from the waist down, though they can appear fully human or fully serpent. Nagas are powerful, wise, and often benevolent beings associated with water‚Äîdwelling in rivers, lakes, seas, wells, and underground realms called Patala. They are guardians of treasures, springs, and the cosmic waters. Famous nagas include Shesha (or Ananta), the thousand-headed serpent on whom Vishnu rests between cosmic cycles; Vasuki, who was used as a rope in the Churning of the Ocean (Samudra Manthan); and Takshaka, the serpent king. Nagas can be both beneficent and malevolent‚Äîthey bring rain and fertility but can also cause floods and disease. They are sworn enemies of Garuda, the eagle-mount of Vishnu. Nagas marry humans in many tales, most famously in the marriage of Ulupi (a naga princess) to Arjuna. They represent the chthonic forces of nature, fertility, immortality (through their ability to shed skin), wisdom, and the kundalini energy in yogic practice.

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Nagas represent the chthonic, aquatic aspects of divinity‚Äîthe powers dwelling beneath the earth and in waters. Their association with water makes them fertility symbols and rain-bringers essential to agricultural prosperity. The ability to shed skin symbolizes rebirth, renewal, and immortality. In yogic tradition, nagas represent kundalini shakti‚Äîthe serpent energy coiled at the base of the spine that rises through chakras to bring enlightenment. Their hood and raised posture represent awakened spiritual power. As underground dwellers guarding treasures, they symbolize hidden wisdom and secret knowledge. Their dual nature (beneficent/malevolent) represents nature's ambivalence‚Äîwater brings life but can also destroy. Shesha supporting Vishnu represents the foundation of cosmic order resting on primordial serpent power. Shiva wearing nagas shows mastery over death and dangerous forces.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Naga worship remains vibrant across South and Southeast Asia. In India, Nag Panchami festival honors nagas with milk offerings at anthills (believed to be naga dwellings). Temple guardians often feature naga imagery. The seven-headed naga hood appears behind Buddha statues (from Mucalinda protecting Buddha during meditation). In Southeast Asia, particularly Thailand, Cambodia, and Laos, naga imagery dominates temple architecture‚Äîbalustrades shaped as nagas connect earthly to divine realms. The naga-princess origin myths legitimate royal dynasties in Southeast Asia. Modern Hindu iconography shows Shiva with naga Vasuki around his neck. Nagas represent the integration of dangerous natural forces into religious practice‚Äîrespecting and appeasing rather than destroying.

mythologyContexts.symbolism: In Buddhism, nagas represent worldly power and riches that can be transformed to serve dharma. Mucalinda's protection of Buddha symbolizes nature's forces bowing to enlightenment. Nagas guarding Buddhist texts represent preservation of wisdom.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Naga imagery is ubiquitous in Buddhist architecture, especially Theravada temples where naga balustrades lead to temple entrances. The seven-headed naga appears behind Buddha images throughout Southeast Asia.
